body:
Please close this PR.
This is the reason why you cannot open a new PR - the commits are added to this one.
I didn't see it was still open

I'll leave this PR to @ivaynberg and @papegaaij.
There are too many CDI/Wicket-CDI internals which I'm not familiar with to merge it.

Because of the issue with the 6.9.0 release and the revert for 6.9.1 I added the ability to enable and disable the anonymous and non-static inner class injection by having the AbstractCdiContainer implementation verify the feature is supported.  In the cdi-weld package, the WeldCdiContainer class checks the specification-version in the manifest of the jar containing WeldBootstrap.class.  If the value is 2.0.2.Final or later the support for anonymous and non-static inner class injection is enabled.  If the version is less than 2.0.2.Final the support is disabled. Also added ability to disable it regardless of version by including the proper init params to the CdiWicketFilter.

I don't think this is needed.
Wicket 7 will be released in few months. I think by then Weld 2.0.2+ should be already integrated in Glassfish/JBoss/...
Users of plain web containers can use any working version of Weld without problems.

Well Glassfish 4 still uses 2.0.0.sp1. I say we leave it until Glassfish4
is well past sp1. Once sp1 is non longer used then we can just remove it.
 This is the nice part of leaving it in the experimental package IMO. Also
the pattern to implement that feature is also designed to expose container
specific features in the future. I designed it as it is to have a mechanism
to allow the core to ask the implementation for support of container
specific features.  When openwebbeans supports cdi 1.1 we may have to
handle some things slightly different and it is nice to already have the
code to do that.

On Mon, Jul 8, 2013 at 3:44 PM, Martin Grigorov notifications@github.comwrote:

> I don't think this is needed.
> Wicket 7 will be released in few months. I think by then Weld 2.0.2+
> should be already integrated in Glassfish/JBoss/...
> Users of plain web containers can use any working version of Weld without
> problems.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/49#issuecomment-20630820
> .
without this feature developing wicket+cdi apps is pretty useless so i would leave it always enabled. perhaps stderr a big warning if weld<2.0.2

It just disables anonymous inner class and non-static inner class injection
if not supported.  Everything else is injected like normal. Personally I
have yet to find a use case where I needed to put @Inject in an anonymous
or non-static inner.  In both of those cases putting the @Inject at the top
level works just fine, and unit testable. If anyone could show me a good
reason why it makes since to @Inject in the anonymous or no-static inner
class then I am all ears.

As for the stderr, the code log.warns that the feature is not supported by
${specification-title} ${specification-version} the first time it is
attempted.

John

On Mon, Jul 8, 2013 at 4:49 PM, Igor Vaynberg notifications@github.comwrote:

> without this feature developing wicket+cdi apps is pretty useless so i
> would leave it always enabled. perhaps stderr a big warning if weld<2.0.2
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/49#issuecomment-20634926
> .

That's a good point.  So should I just rip that code out and not support
glassfish until they move to 2.0.2.Final or later? I think leave the
enable/disable since its automatic until all the app servers are at
2.0.2.Final or later.  I could remove the init-param enable/disable option
and just let the automatic part work.  That keeps it working for all app
servers now. After all app servers have update weld-impl then remove it
fully.

+1 leave it for now remove it when no longer needed.

No opinion on init-param option just added it so developer could disable it
for whatever reason.

John

On Mon, Jul 8, 2013 at 5:43 PM, Igor Vaynberg notifications@github.comwrote:

> it is very common to factor out non-trivial components into inner classes.
> for example, ShoppingCartPage might have BuyButton, ClearAllButton,
> UpdateButton, etc as inner non-static classes. depending on how big they
> are sometimes its easier to inject dependencies directly into them because
> its easier to track when looking at code. sometimes buttons need
> dependencies that only they use, so it again makes sense to inject the
> button directly. yet, other times it actually makes a difference which
> class you inject:
> 
> public class CartPage extends WebPage {
>    class BuyButton extends Button {
> 
> ```
>   @Inject Logger logger;
> 
>   onSubmit() {
>    // do submit stuff
>    logger.info("..");
>   }
> ```
> 
>   }
> }
> 
> i want the logger to use the BuyButton class name as the category instead
> of the CartPage so i have to inject it into BuyButton.
> 
> anyways, it is very common to have a lot of complex anonymous and inner
> classes as wicket components - after all thats the point of wicket.
> 
> -1 on the enable/disable part.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/49#issuecomment-20638381
> .
i would rip it out. it should fail loudly on app-servers with broken support. otherwise it will be a big surprise when someone tries to deploy an existing app on glassfish.

The check is now removed.  If using Glassfish 4 Download weld-osgi-bundle.jar version 2.0.2.Final or later and replace weld-osgi-bundle.jar located in ${glassfish4.home}/glassfish/modules. If using tomcat/jetty make sure you use weld-servlet-2.0.2.Final or later.

Has anyone had a chance to look at PR besides Martin?  The weld-2.0.0.sp1
check is ripped out as requested.

Thanks
John

On Mon, Jul 8, 2013 at 10:34 AM, Martin Grigorov
notifications@github.comwrote:

> I'll leave this PR to @ivaynberg https://github.com/ivaynberg and
> @papegaaij https://github.com/papegaaij.
> There are too many CDI/Wicket-CDI internals which I'm not familiar with to
> merge it.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/49#issuecomment-20609484
> .
sorry, not yet.

No problem just being a squeaky wheel, also in the current version in main
I didn't account for multiple wicket apps in a war. (Bonehead move), but I
fixed that in this rev, plus the CdiWicketFilter is a nice addition. I also
disabled the search for any ConversationalComponent in the tree for now and
wanted to bring up a discussion about that after this PR was in main.  I
had no opinion of the usefulness of it just wanted to get all the other
changes in first, then revisit that feature.

Thanks
John

If you prefer to skip this patch, run "git am --skip" instead.
To restore the original branch and stop patching, run "git am --abort".
```

can you please rebase it so it applies cleanly? thanks.
Rebased and squashed commits.  Closing this PR and opening the rebased version.

I don't think we need this PR. It could easily be accomplished by overriding newMessageDisplayComponent or by the following change:

https://gist.github.com/jthomerson/6595716

Applied with https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-5362.
Will be part of Wicket 6.12 and 7.0.
Danke! :)
Please close the PR because we can't.
thanks :)

Thank you for the pull request. Do you have any idea on the impact of upgrading to atmosphere 2? wicket-atmosphere is an experimental module, so I can change the API, but I'd rather not change it too much. Should we wait for Wicket 7, or is the impact small enough to put it in 6?

I think the impact of the upgrade is small and won't cause too much (if any) regressions. I did a quick check of basic functionality after the upgrade and it seems to be OK. The important thing is that Atmosphere 2.0 release contains lots of bugfixes, so it good to have it!
I've merged the pull request.
So does including this require some discussion ahead or a JIRA ticket?
Commit 2ab4c7c00d2207 removes the .settings files thnx

Replaced by:

https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/58
I've checked the code in Wicket 7, and did make some changes (see the git log on wicket-6.x). Most of it seems ok and with the small modifications, it works fine on our application.

I only backported wicket-cdi-1.1 from Wicket 7 to Wicket 6. Once I've got everything working, I'll forward port my changes to Wicket 7. I did not use this PR. It's impossible to verify the diffs in this PR: all kinds of things are mixed, it contains merges, formatting changes, etc.

but wicket-cdi-1.1 in master was based on that PR...

-igor

wicket-cdi-1.1 was introduced by earlier PRs (47 and 48, I think).
This PR was too complex/radical for me as non-CDI user, so I asked for help with its review.

Igor,
In our conversations throughout the day I thought it was about my early
pulls, because my latest pull request could not properly merged. After
rereading that papegaaij had pulled and fixed my latest code, I will go
into defense mode on what you do not agree with.  Not to start some
flame-war, but to fix what you do not like and the community agrees is the
wrong approach.  The code before that should not be in a release. As for
why I refactored the original cdi-1.0 code to use cdi for injection rather
than constructor instantiate is because once the dependency is there, I
leveraged it.  Was it broke before, NO.  Was it essential to refactor it,
of course not, but now it is easier to create test cases.  Did I break
wicket just to add cdi-1.1, not at all.  So even though I updated your code
base and refactored to use cdi injection even in the low level
implementation classes, I really didn't alter the core functionality. It
still supports cdi-1.0 code. It now allows injection at the instantiation
of the App, it supports the Auto with a finer granularity.  To me it is
still your code with some assistance from me to get it to 1.1.

John

my primary concern is the removal of features like auto conversations. i
know you are still working on a fix, but its not done yet. i do not want to
lose any functionality.

my second concern is that a lot of code has changed and no one went through
it to see if it aligns with how we do things. i found a lot of instances
where it does not.

my third concern is that the api has somewhat changed. i dont really see a
reason for that unless its really necessary.

ideally the pull requests wouldve gone like this (had they i mightve had
time to review them a lot sooner):
- clone wicket-cdi into wicket-cdi-1.1+weld. minimal changes to remove seam
  module conversation management and replace with weld-dependent interfaces.
- refactor auto-conversation management api, i noticed you were doing some
  of that in your changes, but they are too messy (code formatting tweaks)
  and too mixed in with everything else to clearly see what you were trying
  to accomplish
- refactor to allow management of application using cdi lifecycle.

if they were separated like that we can easily follow and
apply/reject/refine your changes individually. as it stands now its more of
a all or nothing approach...

-igor

i write this code using ASL2 license, so i dont mind when other people take it, i give up my ownership at commit. its not about whose code it is or how much youve changed it, its a question of whether its changed for the better. at some point i will be using this code so i just want to make sure that i have a good experience using it. it may seem selfish, but its also why i contribute this code - so others can make it better.

In the latest revision, the AutoConversation is supported.  Just add
@Conversational to the class.  If you want to do it the cdi-1.0 way then
implement ConversationalComponent as , which was modified to have the
@Conversational annotation. The Conversational annotation also adds some
properties, prop and auto.  prop allows the reconfiguration of the
ConversationPropagation for the particular Page without affecting the
global ConversationPropagation set at the Application Instantiation.  The
auto property allows for the Page to override the auto property set
globally by the Application for the Session.  Nothing broke just allows for
page level reconfiguration.

Or the first commit can be dropped, not sure whether it covers something of importance, it is just an example.
Also the actual fix might be overly complicated, just printing getModel() might be enough additional information for developers to understand why a property could not be resolved.

The tests fail with:

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Could not resolve Bean Property from component: [TextField [Component id = input21]]. (Hints:) Possible causes are a typo in the PropertyExpression, a null reference or a model that does not work in combination with a IPropertyResolver. Model : Model:classname=[org.apache.wicket.model.PropertyModel]:nestedModel=[[Page class = org.apache.wicket.bean.validation.PropertyValidatorRequiredTest$TestPage, id = 0, render count = 1]]:expression=[bean.subBeanList[0].property]
    at org.apache.wicket.bean.validation.PropertyValidator.getProperty(PropertyValidator.java:138)
    at org.apache.wicket.bean.validation.PropertyValidator.findNotNullConstraints(PropertyValidator.java:211)
```

Sorry, too tired. The error was intentional to show the previously confusing message. To merge the change to the test needs to be reverted, or fixed:

```
List<TestContainedBean> subBeanList = Arrays.asList(new TestContainedBean());
```
added commit fixing the test

After merging this PR to wicket-6.x the following tests fail:

```
Failed tests:   optionPlaceholderDecode1(org.apache.wicket.core.request.mapper.MountedMapperTest)
  optionPlaceholderDecodeEagerMatchParameters(org.apache.wicket.core.request.mapper.MountedMapperTest)
  optionPlaceholderDecode2(org.apache.wicket.core.request.mapper.MountedMapperTest)
  optionPlaceholderDecode3(org.apache.wicket.core.request.mapper.MountedMapperTest)
  optionPlaceholderDecodeWithIndexParams(org.apache.wicket.core.request.mapper.MountedMapperTest)
  optionPlaceholderEncode1(org.apache.wicket.core.request.mapper.MountedMapperTest): expected:<some/[p1/path/p2/i1/i2?a=b&b=c]> but was:<some/[/i1/i2?a=b&b=c&param1=p1&param2=p2]>
  optionPlaceholderEncode2(org.apache.wicket.core.request.mapper.MountedMapperTest): expected:<some/[path/p2/p3/i1/i2?a=b&b=c]> but was:<some/[/i1/i2?a=b&b=c&param2=p2&param3=p3]>
```

I'll investigate.
Thanks!

Integrated:

The knowledge is there: https://github.com/apache/wicket/blob/master/wicket-core/src/main/java/org/apache/wicket/request/resource/CssPackageResource.java#L65
The problem is that it is not propagated.
I.e. CssPackageResource knows the scope class, but it doesn't give it to the ICssCompressor.
What do you think of leaving the check of page away in the first step and then implement your suggestions in a further pull request?

Ok I think I got it, but the changes are not backward compatible to wicket 6.x. I would really suggest to put the current classes at the repository and later on apply changes and add a IScopedAwareProcessor

So for now, yep the CssUrlReplacer is a bit slow, because it is scanning for the images in different scopes and it is a limitation that you can not put images in other packages as those of the components, but I would recommend to apply the changes of @martin-g in a separate pull request, because they require modifications in various classes and they are not backward compatible. What do you think?
